config.question: Why did many European nations abandon silver coinage, late in the nineteenth century, in favor of gold?

choices.content: American silver production had significantly increased, thereby lowering its price.
The reduced availability of silver had made it costlier than ever before.
Gold was more abundant than silver in most European nations.
European nations wanted to challenge the gold-oriented northern states.

answer_3.response: American silver production quadrupled between 1870 and 1890, glutting the world market, lowering the price of silver, and persuading many European nations to abandon silver coinage in favor of the scarcer metal, gold.
